heading: 5 Time Series Analysis in R
text: Sebastian Carter

heading: 5.1 Introducing Time Series
text: Time series data consists observations collected period time. Often times time series, observations affected previous (many preceding) points. example, suppose collecting wind speed data. obvious wind speed current moment time dependent wind speed one minute ago. characteristic makes time series analysis unique area study requires us build understanding education linear regression. linear regression, make key assumption error terms independent. However, crucially, time series data often case.

heading: 5.1.1 EDA of Time Series Data
text:
Time series data often seasonal component, trend component, error term. familiar linear regression model,
\[
Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1X_i + \epsilon_i
\]
qualitatively,
\[
Y = \text{trend} + \epsilon .
\]Similarly, can write time series data following form:\[
Y_t = \text{seasonal}_t + \text{trend}_t + \epsilon_t
\]equation, denoted \(\{Y_t\}\) time series data interest, say wind speed. Eventually, attempt ‚Äúde-trend‚Äù \(\{Y_t\}\), essentially means removing seasonal trend component data. First, let‚Äôs examine methods identify components.use decompose function, helpful tool data scientists conduct quick analysis seasonal trend components time series data.

heading: 5.1.1.1 Example
text: example, examine maximum temperature Boston per month. first plot displays measured data. second plot displays trend, typically calculated using moving average. Next, season trend determined displayed. final plot displays residuals, data subtracting trend seasonal components data.
code:
BosTemp = read.csv("resources/timeseriesanalysis/boston_monthly_tmax_1998_2019.csv")

BosTemp$DateTime = as.Date(BosTemp$Date, "%m/%d/%Y")
ts(BosTemp[,2], frequency = 12, start = c(1998,1)) %>% decompose %>% autoplot

heading: 5.1.1.1.1 Important Data Wrangling
text: data visualization tools, decompose() autoplot() functions take ts object. decompose function accept dataframe time series data familiar . must convert dataframe time series object.preview data loaded.ts function can used convert dataframe time series object. first argument ts function take data (vector matrix form), ‚Äústart‚Äù argument takes time first observation, frequency function takes number observations per unit time. , example, monthly data starts 1998, start = 1998 frequency = 12., Boston temperature data converted time series object, accepted autoplot().

heading: 5.1.2 Autocorrelation Plot (ACF)
text: de-trended data, want examine residuals order understand error structure (eventually able forecast). Autocorrelation Plot (ACF) important tool time series EDA can give us insights error structure help us determine appropriate model. ACF plot basically calculates displays correlation coefficient time series lagged values. example, lag 1 autocorrelation correlation \(X_t\) \(X_{t-1}\) \(t>1\). Likewise, lag 2 autocorrelation autocorrelation \(X_t\) \(X_{t-2}\), .e.¬†correlation \(t^{th}\) observation \({(t-2)}^{th}\) observation.use ggacf function within bayesforecast package create autocorrelation plot (also known correlogram).

heading: 5.1.2.1 Example
text: iid error, expect correlation lags. acf plot iid error. multiple black lines cross dashed blue line boundaries, may reject null hypothesis lags uncorrelated.
code:
t = 1:100
error = rnorm(100)
Y = 2*t +error 

df = data.frame(t, Y)

model = lm(Y ~ t, data = df)

ggacf(residuals((model)))

heading: 5.1.2.2 Example
text: Now, let‚Äôs examine case errors correlated, demonstrate ACF plot useful identifying characteristic. , use Boston temperature dataset.Clearly, observe harmonic trend, since removed seasonal trend components data. However, can extract de-trended time series data decompose function used earlier. residuals look much iid , good first step modelling time series data.

heading: 5.1.3 Partial Autocorrelation Plot (PACF)
text: PACF similar ACF plot displays autocorrelation observations lags, however PACF removes effects lags. Intuitively speaking, observations affected previous observation, see high correlation coefficient lag 1. However, thinking recursively, mean observation also affected lag 2 (.e.¬†lag 1 lag 1). result, ACF plot, see significant correlation coefficient lag 2, forth (albeit muted lag 1). PACF plot, however, eliminates influence lags. , AR(p) process, time series model basically determines relationship observation previous p observations, can use PACF plot determine p.¬†

heading: 5.1.3.1 Example
text: , let‚Äôs use dataset can bring together everything looked far ‚Äì decompose function, autoplot, acf plot finally pacf ‚Äì go step attempt identify suitable model using acf/pacf plots.Based acf plot, can definitely see AR(p) process suitable, since first lags high correlation coefficients. Now, let‚Äôs use pacf plot investigate .Based plot , can estimate AR(2) AR(3) model might suitable, since correlation coefficients get close zero starting around lag 3 lag 4.
code:
Ex_data = read.csv("resources/timeseriesanalysis/TS_data.csv")

Ex_data_ts = ts(Ex_data[,2], start = 1900, frequency = 2)

ggacf(Ex_data_ts)
Ex_data_ts %>% decompose() %>% autoplot()
ggacf((Ex_data_ts %>% decompose())$random)
ggpacf((Ex_data_ts %>% decompose())$random)

heading: 5.1.4 Forecasting
text:
Forecasting time series data one important aspects time series analysis. order forecast, examine certain properties time series processes (AR, MA, ARMA) believe estimate data well. reference, AR(1), MA(1) ARMA(1,1) models written , respectively.\[
X_t = \phi X_{t-1} +Z_t, Z_t  \sim WN(0,\sigma^2)
\]\[
X_t =  \theta Z_{t-1} + Z_t, Z_t  \sim WN(0,\sigma^2)
\]\[
X_t - \phi X_{t-1} =  Z_t + \theta Z_{t-1} , Z_t  \sim WN(0,\sigma^2)
\]Causality Invertibility essential characteristics time series process. Causality implies time series process can estimated using past observations (opposed future observations) invertibility means errors (see \(Z_t\) terms) can represented past observations. Without getting mathematics behind , causality can determined analyzing roots \(X_t - \phi X_{t-1}\) polynomial. absolute values roots greater 1, say process causal.Similarly, invertibility can determined analysing roots \(Z_t + \theta Z_{t-1}\) polynomial. absolute values roots greater 1, say process invertible.R useful function allows us quickly easily determine roots therefore examine causality invertibility time series process.

heading: 5.1.4.1 Example
text: Extending upon data PACF example, determine causality using roots method. can use Arima() function forecast package order model data, autoplot() function visualise unit circle inverse roots. inverse roots within circle, time series causal. Per analysis conducted using PACF plot, use AR(3) model data.
code:
Ex_data$X_1 = NA 
Ex_data$X_1[2:200] = Ex_data$X[1:199]

Ex_data$X_2 = NA 
Ex_data$X_2[3:200] = Ex_data$X[1:198]

Ex_data$X_3 = NA 
Ex_data$X_3[4:200] = Ex_data$X[1:197]

model = lm(X ~ X_1 +X_2 +X_3 , data = Ex_data)

summary(model) ## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = X ~ X_1 + X_2 + X_3, data = Ex_data)
## 
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -1.5192 -0.5453  0.0193  0.4628  1.8945 
## 
## Coefficients:
##             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)  0.36799    0.14234   2.585   0.0105 *  
## X_1          0.29241    0.07153   4.088 6.38e-05 ***
## X_2          0.72885    0.05236  13.921  < 2e-16 ***
## X_3         -0.13416    0.07100  -1.890   0.0603 .  
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 0.7006 on 193 degrees of freedom
##   (3 observations deleted due to missingness)
## Multiple R-squared:  0.7362, Adjusted R-squared:  0.7321 
## F-statistic: 179.6 on 3 and 193 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16
Ex_data_ts %>% 
  Arima(order = c(3,0,0))%>% autoplot

heading: 5.1.4.2 More examples
text: order drive home concept, simulate couple AR ARMA processes visualise unit roots.

heading: 5.1.4.2.1 ARMA(3,2)
code:
my_ARMA_sim <- function(n,ma_coeff,ar_coeff,sigma=1) {
  n.start <- n + floor(.2/(1-.2)*n)
  burnin <- floor(.20*n.start)
  model_params <- list(ma = ma_coeff,ar=ar_coeff)
  ts_sim <- arima.sim(model = model_params, n = n.start,sd=sigma)
  ts_sim <- ts_sim[(burnin+1):n.start]
  return(ts_sim) 
}

n=1000
ar_coeff=c(.4,.4,.1)
ma_coeff=c(.4,.5)
sigma <- 1
AMRA_sim <- my_ARMA_sim(n=n,ma_coeff=ma_coeff,ar_coeff=ar_coeff,sigma=sigma)

ts(AMRA_sim, frequency = 10, start = c(1900)) %>% 
  Arima(order = c(3,0,2))%>% autoplot

heading: 5.1.4.2.2 AR(2)
code:
my_AR_sim <- function(n=189, ar_coeff,sigma=1) {
    n.start <- n + floor(.2/(1-.2)*n)
    burnin <- floor(.20*n.start)
    model_params <- list(ar = ar_coeff)
    ts_sim <- arima.sim(model = model_params, n = n.start,sd=sigma)
    ts_sim <- ts_sim[(burnin+1):n.start]
    return(ts_sim)
}

ar_sim <- my_AR_sim(n=n,ar_coeff=0.5,sigma=sigma)

ts(ar_sim, frequency = 1, start = c(1900)) %>% 
  Arima(order = c(1,0,0))%>% autoplot

heading: 5.1.4.3 Forecasting Functions
text: conducting EDA examining causality/invertibility, can begin forecasting. R functions helpful area. forecast package includes function called forecast takes model parameter extrapolates future time periods. ets function exponential smoothing model. blue line represents estimated value shaded purple areas confidence bands estimate.can also use Arima function estimate ARMA model use forecast future values. Using ARIMA simulated AR(2) model created earlier.
code:
USAccDeaths %>%
  ets() %>%
  forecast() %>%
  autoplot()
ts(ar_sim, frequency = 1, start = c(1900)) %>% 
  Arima(order = c(2,0,0)) %>%
  forecast() %>% 
  autoplot(ylab = "Simulated AR(2)")

Whilst basic understanding fundamental time series concepts, project strengthened grasp time series analysis exposed practical methods applying theory R. Additionally, feel creating tutorial helped better understand theoretical concepts time series identify significance (‚Äú‚Äù) many theories. found helpful connect time series concepts linear regression concepts trained statistics students. came realize time series builds expands many concepts familiar stats training far.
